commit_message:
Add tempest and cap oslo.messaging/tempest version

Cap oslo.messaging to 5.17.1, the latest version has been deprecated
notifer 'topic' which takes issues in ceilometer mitaka version.

add tempest to test-requirements.txt

Closes-Bug: #1573654
(cherry picked from commit be8c615bb0e8a30275e31cc2221213d70eb9611d)

Cap tempest to 12.2.0 as the call_until_true has been deprecated after
13.0.0.

test.call_until_true has been deprecated since Newton on Tempest side,
and now Tempest provides test_utils.call_until_true as the stable
library method. So this patch switches to use the stable method before
removing old test.call_until_true on Tempest side.

(cherry picked from commit d46c28b30c10fd1f6718add98be9cfc8682b3f8b)

Change-Id: I7e18b14c6dcfc21e47b0e90ebd2fc17936377c25

commit_message:
Update instead of replacing the environment file

Currently the entire environment file is replaced,
which may remove any existing configuration on the
hosts including any pre-existing proxy configurations
and anything else the deployer may have put there.

This method replaces it with an additive process which
respects pre-existing content, but still allows the
global_environment_variables variable changes to be
fully reflected in the resulting environment file.

As the PATH setting in the previous template was
the default path which will already be present in
the container, that has been removed from the template.

Change-Id: I930f1711fbd56d2c97e8c80bd990350fa0c7ba73

added_lines: $ docker build https://git.openstack.org/openstack/loci-keystone.git#:debian --tag keystone:latest * The git repo containing the OpenStack project the container should contain, `PROJECT_REPO` * The git ref or branch the container should fetch for the project, `PROJECT_REF` * The git repo containing the common install scripts, `SCRIPTS_REPO` * The git ref or branch the container should fetch for the scripts, `SCRIPTS_REF` * To inject anything into the image before hand (sources.list, keys, etc), create a tarball and reference its location, `OVERRIDE`$ docker build https://git.openstack.org/openstack/loci-keystone.git#:debian \ --build-arg PROJECT_REPO=http://git.openstack.org/openstack/keystone.git \ --build-arg PROJECT_REF=refs/changes/67/418167/1
deleted_lines: $ docker build https://github.com/openstack/loci-keystone.git#:debian --tag keystone:latest * The git repo containing the OpenStack project the container should contain, `GIT_REPO` * The git ref the container should use when building, `GIT_REF` * The git repo the container should use when building from a git ref, `GIT_REF_REPO`$ docker build https://github.com/openstack/loci-keystone.git#:debian \ --build-arg GIT_REPO=http://git.openstack.org/openstack/keystone.git \ --build-arg GIT_REF_REPO=http://git.openstack.org/openstack/keystone.git \ --build-arg GIT_REF=refs/changes/67/418167/1

that looks like 'keystone-0.0.0' which is bad.

This has a second purpose of allowing us to take advantage of
zuul-cloner. zuul-cloner does the proper merger of things for patches
that use Depends-On or are in a patch chain. Additionally, it uses the
local /opt/git git cache to futher reduce the fetching.

Change-Id: Ic0978dbb8e465b33c603d4151ec00922b206df48
"}]
commit_message:
Use local git server for clones

Getting the history from a fetch is required to allow PBR to fetch the
project version and install. With '--depth 1' you'll see an install
that looks like 'keystone-0.0.0' which is bad.

This has a second purpose of allowing us to take advantage of
zuul-cloner. zuul-cloner does the proper merger of things for patches
that use Depends-On or are in a patch chain. Additionally, it uses the
local /opt/git git cache to futher reduce the fetching.

Change-Id: Ic0978dbb8e465b33c603d4151ec00922b206df48

commit_message:
Copy host environment file into cache

In an environment when a proxy has been configured for internet
access (in /etc/environment), the cache prep will need to also
be configured to make use of it. Currently the onlly way to work
around this is to have a mirror which is accessible without using
a proxy.

This patch ensures that the /etc/environment file is copied into
the LXC cache prior to executing anything in the chroot. This
should ensure that the cache prep can use the same proxy that is
configured on the host.

Change-Id: I4deb7e0a35a0364ceb57b9a12f283ac7439d5e8a

commit_message:
Add a basic glance API tests

One script will loop over the glance image list and collect response
times in a common logging format.

The other attempts to upload a small binary file to the glance store in
order to see a 'real' use case.

Change-Id: I2d2aabb802774e28746be7eabafb0578998fdd37

added_lines: #!/usr/bin/env python # Copyright 2017, Rackspace US, Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); # you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. # You may obtain a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, # WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. # See the License for the specific language governing permissions and # limitations under the License. # # (c) 2017, Nolan Brubaker <nolan.brubaker@rackspace.com> import datetime from glanceclient import Client from keystoneauth1.identity import v3 from keystoneauth1 import session from keystoneclient.v3 import client as key_client import logging import os import sys import time logger = logging.getLogger(__name__) def configure_logging(): logger.setLevel(logging.INFO) console = logging.StreamHandler() logfile = logging.FileHandler('/var/log/glance_query.log', 'a') console.setLevel(logging.INFO) logfile.setLevel(logging.INFO) formatter = logging.Formatter('%(asctime)s - %(levelname)s - %(message)s') console.setFormatter(formatter) logfile.setFormatter(formatter) logger.addHandler(console) logger.addHandler(logfile) configure_logging() def get_session(): auth_url = os.environ['OS_AUTH_URL'] password = os.environ['OS_PASSWORD'] auth = v3.Password(auth_url=auth_url, username="admin", password=password, project_name="admin", user_domain_id="default", project_domain_id="default") sess = session.Session(auth=auth) return sess def get_keystone_client(session): return key_client.Client(session=session) def get_glance_endpoint(keystone): service_id = keystone.services.find(name='glance') glance_endpoint = keystone.endpoints.list(service=service_id, interface='admin')[0] # The glance client wants the URL, not the keystone object return glance_endpoint.url try: while True: time.sleep(1) start_time = datetime.datetime.now() sess = get_session() keystone = get_keystone_client(sess) endpoint = get_glance_endpoint(keystone) glance = Client(version='2', endpoint=endpoint, session=sess) # The image.list method returns a generator, but we just care about # response time image_list = glance.images.list() end_time = datetime.datetime.now() delta = end_time - start_time logger.info("New list {}s".format(delta.total_seconds())) except KeyboardInterrupt: sys.exit()

commit_message:
Update hacking version

we had quite an old one, and updating to what's curently in g-r found
only one violation, so better to fix it now.

Also improve import order checking and add more checks (mostly in line
to what openstack/ironic does).

Change-Id: I9bca6c121bdcdfc1de22c1ce857c3fa09ce072bb

commit_message:
Add AggregateMultiTenancyIsolation filter tests

This change adds four new testcases that verify whether the
tenancy based isolation works correctly.

Also did some refactoring to avoid clones in the code base.

Change-Id: I932aeb16c300ada1c1dbaba282c8253decec314b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/87/374887/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from oslo_log import log as logging from tempest.common.utils import data_utils from tempest.common import waiters from tempest import config from tempest import exceptions from tempest.scenario import manager from tempest import test CONF = config.CONF LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) class TestAggregateMultiTenancyIsolation(manager.AggregatesScenarioTest): """Tests aggregates isolation""" _host_key = "OS-EXT-SRV-ATTR:host" @classmethod def skip_checks(cls): super(TestAggregateMultiTenancyIsolation, cls).skip_checks() filter = 'AggregateMultiTenancyIsolation' if not test.is_scheduler_filter_enabled(filter): raise cls.skipException( "AggregateMultiTenancyIsolation is disabled") @classmethod def setup_credentials(cls): super(TestAggregateMultiTenancyIsolation, cls).setup_credentials() def _create_tenant(self): name = data_utils.rand_name('aggregate') desc = data_utils.rand_name('desc') tenants_client = self.manager.tenants_client tenant = tenants_client.create_tenant(name=name, description=desc)['tenant'] tenant_id = tenant['id'] LOG.debug("Created new tenant: %s" % tenant_id) self.addCleanup(tenants_client.delete_tenant, tenant_id) return tenant_id def _get_instance_hostname(self, server_id): server = self.servers_client.show_server(server_id)['server'] hostname = server[self._host_key] LOG.debug("Server runs on: %s" % hostname) return hostname def _get_all_host_names(self): hosts = self.hosts_client.list_hosts()['hosts'] self.assertGreater(len(hosts), 0, "Deployment contains 0 compute hosts.") computes = [x['host_name'] for x in hosts if x['service'] == 'compute'] return computes def _create_aggregate_with_tenant_filter(self, use_default_tenant=True): aggregate_name = data_utils.rand_name('aggregate-scenario') aggregate = self._create_aggregate(name=aggregate_name) if use_default_tenant: tenant_id = self.manager.identity_client.tenant_id else: tenant_id = self._create_tenant() metadata = {'filter_tenant_id': tenant_id} self._set_aggregate_metadata(aggregate, metadata) self._check_aggregate_details(aggregate, aggregate_name, metadata=metadata) return aggregate @test.attr(type='smoke') @test.idempotent_id('a795e02f-900b-4811-aa43-24420547531f') @test.services('compute') def test_aggregate_one_valid_host(self): aggregate_for_default_tenant = \ self._create_aggregate_with_tenant_filter() aggregate_for_tenant_2 = \ self._create_aggregate_with_tenant_filter(use_default_tenant=False) # Split all compute hosts between the two aggregates: # one compute belongs to the first, # the rest of the computes belong the second aggregate hosts = self._get_all_host_names() self._add_host(aggregate_for_default_tenant['id'], hosts[0]) for h in hosts[1:]: self._add_host(aggregate_for_tenant_2['id'], h) self._check_aggregate_details(aggregate_for_default_tenant, hosts=[hosts[0]]) self._check_aggregate_details(aggregate_for_tenant_2, hosts=hosts[1:]) server = self.create_server(wait_until='ACTIVE') host = self._get_instance_hostname(server['id']) self.assertEqual(hosts[0], host) @test.attr(type='smoke') @test.idempotent_id('bcb57526-fc01-4574-809b-59a38d4688b0') @test.services('compute') def test_aggregate_host_shared_between_tenants(self): aggregate_for_default_tenant = \ self._create_aggregate_with_tenant_filter() aggregate_for_tenant_2 = \ self._create_aggregate_with_tenant_filter(use_default_tenant=False) # The first compute belongs to both aggregates, # the rest of the computes belong only to the second aggregate hosts = self._get_all_host_names() self._add_host(aggregate_for_default_tenant['id'], hosts[0]) for h in hosts: self._add_host(aggregate_for_tenant_2['id'], h) self._check_aggregate_details(aggregate_for_default_tenant, hosts=[hosts[0]]) self._check_aggregate_details(aggregate_for_tenant_2, hosts=hosts) server = self.create_server(wait_until='ACTIVE') host = self._get_instance_hostname(server['id']) self.assertEqual(hosts[0], host) @test.attr(type='smoke') @test.idempotent_id('ada476c0-677e-408b-9cf7-a615ad2c0ad5') @test.services('compute') def test_aggregate_without_tenant_metadata(self): aggregate_for_tenant_2 = \ self._create_aggregate_with_tenant_filter(use_default_tenant=False) # The first compute does not belong to any aggregate therefore # it belongs to every tenant hosts = self._get_all_host_names() for h in hosts[1:]: self._add_host(aggregate_for_tenant_2['id'], h) self._check_aggregate_details(aggregate_for_tenant_2, hosts=hosts[1:]) server = self.create_server(wait_until='ACTIVE') host = self._get_instance_hostname(server['id']) self.assertEqual(hosts[0], host) @test.attr(type=['negative', 'smoke']) @test.idempotent_id('c72eef51-94cb-473d-8aba-b23cb857535e') @test.services('compute') def test_aggregate_no_free_host(self): aggregate_for_tenant_2 = \ self._create_aggregate_with_tenant_filter(use_default_tenant=False) # All computes belong to an aggregate which is marked with # a non-default tenant id hosts = self._get_all_host_names() for host in hosts: self._add_host(aggregate_for_tenant_2['id'], host) self._check_aggregate_details(aggregate_for_tenant_2, hosts=hosts) server = self.create_server() host = self._get_instance_hostname(server['id']) self.assertRaises(exceptions.BuildErrorException, waiters.wait_for_server_status, self.servers_client, server['id'], 'ACTIVE')

commit_message:
Bump Keepalived

This bump will fix a configuration bug ([1]), and introduce
timeout feature [2] and SUSE support [3].

The downside is that a restart of keepalived will happen.

[1]: https://github.com/evrardjp/ansible-keepalived/commit/afb581f7fb6f1f35cf525949035a68540d52b4a7
[2]: https://github.com/evrardjp/ansible-keepalived/commit/0b2d13a13c1a03e14ac6f67286811ca1bf1928ac
[3]: https://github.com/evrardjp/ansible-keepalived/commit/e815ac3321fa18b346680366ad155e784298821e

Change-Id: I4d637bff6f86408e882f580ff1e11580a1011824
(cherry picked from commit 29f5fa971dd982924593752cc67470ac583d48ef)

commit_message:
VMAX driver - superfluous debug messages causing error

When creating a boot volume, there is an error that is thrown
when the volume is the only volume in the default storage group.

Change-Id: I34b411301659eef768de5b20853b00911fae06a8
Closes-Bug: #1664630
(cherry picked from commit d7c63ed092a3c80ea5f2285baaf3b44ca8918414)

commit_message:
VMAX driver - volumes part of CG not managed correctly

Volumes created as part of a clone CG operation (either from the
source CG or a CG snapshot) were not managed properly. This was
because the provider_location was not being set as part of the
volume_model_update. With this fix, the provider_location is set
properly for the new target Volumes which are created as part of
the cloning of the CG. Additionally, a random UUID is generated
before creating the volume and is assigned as the name of the
volume on VMAX. This UUID is stored as a part of a key-value pair
in the volume.s admin metadata. This UUID is used later to uniquely
identify the volume on the VMAX while doing a volume operation.

Change-Id: I16ab7e25202c8ce861d8654097cf17fcf9bc8295
Closes-Bug: #1669827
(cherry picked from commit 5f5ddd9c40f3926dbe2360d4187c274ebeaf42b0)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/50/449950/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import uuid targetVolName = None admin_metadata = {} if 'admin_metadata' in volume: admin_metadata = volume.admin_metadata if 'targetVolumeName' in admin_metadata: targetVolName = admin_metadata['targetVolumeName'] # Check if it is a vol created as part of a clone group if not (targetVolName == foundVolumeinstance['ElementName']): foundVolumeinstance = None dictOfVolumeDicts = {} targetVolumeNames = {} # Create a random UUID and use it as volume name targetVolumeName = six.text_type(uuid.uuid4()) volumeDict = self._create_vol_and_add_to_cg( source_vol_or_snapshot['id'], extraSpecs, targetVolumeName) dictOfVolumeDicts[volume['id']] = volumeDict targetVolumeNames[volume['id']] = targetVolumeName # Update the provider_location for volume_model_update in volumes_model_update: if volume_model_update['id'] in dictOfVolumeDicts: volume_model_update.update( {'provider_location': six.text_type( dictOfVolumeDicts[volume_model_update['id']])}) # Update the volumes_model_update with admin_metadata self.update_admin_metadata(volumes_model_update, key='targetVolumeName', values=targetVolumeNames) def update_admin_metadata( self, volumes_model_update, key, values): """Update the volume_model_updates with admin metadata :param volumes_model_update: List of volume model updates :param key: Key to be updated in the admin_metadata :param values: Dictionary of values per volume id """ for volume_model_update in volumes_model_update: volume_id = volume_model_update['id'] if volume_id in values: admin_metadata = {} admin_metadata.update({key: values[volume_id]}) volume_model_update.update( {'admin_metadata': admin_metadata}) targetCgInstanceName, targetCgName, source_id, extraSpecs, targetVolumeName): :param targetVolumeName: volume name for the target volume :returns volumeDict: volume dictionary for the newly created volume return volumeDict
deleted_lines: foundVolumeinstance = None self._create_vol_and_add_to_cg( source_vol_or_snapshot['id'], extraSpecs) targetCgInstanceName, targetCgName, source_id, extraSpecs): targetVolumeName = 'targetVol'

commit_message:
[sec-guide] Edits to the compliance chap

1. Minor editorial changes to the compliance chapter
2. Also creates new 'case studies' folder and moves case
studies into the folder for appropriate reviews.

Change-Id: I3035510a6d66348fdd8ad3e6fce8f2133db7c744
Implements: blueprint sec-guide-overhaul

subject: Lock tox.ini dependencies to stable/ocata
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-04-06 14:04:00.000000000', 'files': ['tox.ini'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova-powervm/commit/dd9cf95076f40bb9970dfbdb8d2984475b757d3d', 'message': 'Lock tox.ini dependencies to stable/ocata

Adjusts the global requirements and nova dependencies in tox.ini to
point to the stable/ocata branch (instead of implicitly master).

commit_message:
Lock tox.ini dependencies to stable/ocata

Adjusts the global requirements and nova dependencies in tox.ini to
point to the stable/ocata branch (instead of implicitly master).

Change-Id: I1127887f230c8c138919057275536286e3bfe466
Closes-Bug: #1680470

commit_message:
Change default db reconnection tries count to -1

This change is needed for cases with big time interval
between Ceilometer services and database backend starting.
Otherwise, Ceilometer API defines storage connection to None
and all storage requests fail permanently.

cherry-picked from bd53bfb

Change-Id: Ic442ff42e225f98a7a06469b2ff77d95fac84e2b
Closes-bug: #1611023

subject: distribute nodes uniformly
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-04-06 01:41:40.000000000', 'files': ['tooz/hashring.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tooz/commit/95e39fe75bbac69fc46698c409252a89f766bc1a', 'message': "distribute nodes uniformly

nodes are currently placed on ring based on hash. this is not
exactly uniform as some nodes will have neighbours that are closer
to it than other nodes, this means all the nodes have a different
weight even if they all have same 'weight' param.

this creates a secondary list which spaces nodes (and vnodes) all
equally so if there is nodeA with weight 1 and nodeB with weight 2,
nodeB actually has 66.6...% of hashring.

Change-Id: Idad0b5c3b828af2a294a1b7b3c9d219a9f2c7619
"}]
commit_message:
distribute nodes uniformly

nodes are currently placed on ring based on hash. this is not
exactly uniform as some nodes will have neighbours that are closer
to it than other nodes, this means all the nodes have a different
weight even if they all have same 'weight' param.

this creates a secondary list which spaces nodes (and vnodes) all
equally so if there is nodeA with weight 1 and nodeB with weight 2,
nodeB actually has 66.6...% of hashring.

Change-Id: Idad0b5c3b828af2a294a1b7b3c9d219a9f2c7619
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tooz refs/changes/44/453944/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: MAX_PARTITIONS = 2**128 - 1 def _uniform_partitions(length): step = HashRing.MAX_PARTITIONS / length return [i * step for i in six.moves.range(length)] @staticmethod size = len(self._partitions) position = bisect.bisect(self._uniform_partitions(size), hashed_key) return position if position < size else 0
deleted_lines: position = bisect.bisect(self._partitions, hashed_key) return position if position < len(self._partitions) else 0

backend store by default. Since glance_backend_file is useless

Change-Id: I94cbd8661e43ab296478470ed57d0effc5622ee5
'}]
commit_message:
Remove useless variable glance_backend_file

When glance_backend_ceph is not enabled, glance uses file as
backend store by default. Since glance_backend_file is useless
and not overriding glance backend when glance_backend_ceph is
enabled. I think it is good to remove it.

Change-Id: I94cbd8661e43ab296478470ed57d0effc5622ee5

commit_message:
ETCD health research: test plan

Change-Id: I893a9449ced14c888f08fdfe903371fecc889c25
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/performance-docs refs/changes/73/453273/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. _Measuring_performance_of_Kargo: ============================================= Measuring performance of Kargo ============================================= :status: **ready** :version: 1.0 :Abstract: This document is a test plan for ETCD health research that should determine a process of getting the dependency between Kubernetes cluster under load and ETCD cluster health state. Test Plan ========= We should obtain the test results by collecting crucial system metrics that provided natively by ETCD/Kubernetes API, compare and normalize them and plot dependency graphs. Test Environment ---------------- Preparation ^^^^^^^^^^^ 1. Monitoring system must be set up and working, basing on the `Monitoring`_ methodology documentation. 2. K8S cluster should be deployed using `Kargo`_ on top of the 430 nodes with preinstalled Ubuntu Xenial. 3. On the one of the K8S master we should check/install the following packages/tools: .. table:: Software to be installed +--------------+---------+-----------------------------------+ | package name | version | source | +==============+=========+===================================+ | `curl`_ | latest | Ubuntu xenial universe repository | +--------------+---------+-----------------------------------+ | `jq`_ | latest | Ubuntu xenial universe repository | +--------------+---------+-----------------------------------+ | `paste`_ | latest | Ubuntu xenial universe repository | +--------------+---------+-----------------------------------+ | `MMM`_ | latest | GitHub | +--------------+---------+-----------------------------------+ | `Hoseproxy`_ | latest | Github | +--------------+---------+-----------------------------------+ Environment description ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ Test results MUST include a description of the environment used. The following items should be included: - **Hardware configuration of each server.** If virtual machines are used then both physical and virtual hardware should be fully documented. An example format is given below: .. table:: Description of server hardware +-------+----------------+-------+-------+ |server |name | | | | +----------------+-------+-------+ | |role | | | | +----------------+-------+-------+ | |vendor,model | | | | +----------------+-------+-------+ | |operating_system| | | +-------+----------------+-------+-------+ |CPU |vendor,model | | | | +----------------+-------+-------+ | |processor_count | | | | +----------------+-------+-------+ | |core_count | | | | +----------------+-------+-------+ | |frequency_MHz | | | +-------+----------------+-------+-------+ |RAM |vendor,model | | | | +----------------+-------+-------+ | |amount_MB | | | +-------+----------------+-------+-------+ |NETWORK|interface_name | | | | +----------------+-------+-------+ | |vendor,model | | | | +----------------+-------+-------+ | |bandwidth | | | +-------+----------------+-------+-------+ |STORAGE|dev_name | | | | +----------------+-------+-------+ | |vendor,model | | | | +----------------+-------+-------+ | |SSD/HDD | | | | +----------------+-------+-------+ | |size | | | +-------+----------------+-------+-------+ - **Configuration of hardware network switches.** The configuration file from the switch can be downloaded and attached. - **Network scheme.** The plan should show how all hardware is connected and how the components communicate. All ethernet/fibrechannel and VLAN channels should be included. Each interface of every hardware component should be matched with the corresponding L2 channel and IP address. Test Cases ---------- Description ^^^^^^^^^^^ There are two specific cases that should be conducted. 1. Load K8S with as much big as possible number of pods per each node. Stop when either of K8S or ETCD degrades or existing limits are reached. 2. Load K8S with as much big as possible number of services. Stop when either of K8S or ETCD degrades or existing limits are reached. List of performance metrics ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ Basing on `CoreOS ETCD`_ documentation, we collected a list of key metrics that define ETCD cluster health state: .. table:: List of performance metrics +-------------------+-------------------+------------------------------------------+ | Metric | Measurement Units | Short description | +===================+===================+==========================================+ | | || The elapsed time deploy ready K8S | | DEPLOYMENT_TIME | seconds || cluster on a different number of nodes. | | | || | +-------------------+-------------------+------------------------------------------+ | | || Total incoming/outgoing network | | NET_ALL | bit/s || bandwidth usage as a function of the | | | || number of nodes. | +-------------------+-------------------+------------------------------------------+ | | || CPU utilization as a function of the | | CPU | percentage || number of nodes. | +-------------------+-------------------+------------------------------------------+ | | || Active memory usage as a function of | | RAM | MB || the number of nodes. | +-------------------+-------------------+------------------------------------------+ | | || Storage total read/write IO bandwidth | | DISK_ALL | operations/second || as a function of the number of nodes. | +-------------------+-------------------+------------------------------------------+ K8S-sided metrics should only define total number of pods/services in the cluster for each moment of time within testing period. Collecting metrics ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ Each required metric could be gathered through `Prometheus API`_ using curl and jq to extract json objects and strip off extra data. For example, let say we need to get `<metric_a>` values within period starting from `<start>` and finishing at `<stop>` with a time step = `<step>`. Prometheus IP address is `<prometheus_server>`. Resulted query will look like: .. code:: bash curl -q 'http://<prometheus_server>/api/v1/query_range?query=<metric_a>&start=<start>&end=<end>&step=<step>' Ploting 'K8S vs ETCD dependency' ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ After obtaining metrics for each case, we need to make plots showing dependency between K8S pods/services number and corresponding metric. It's better to merge collected metrics in two csv files (for each case) in order to make plots easily using third-party instruments like `Google sheets`_ or `Plotly`_. Reports ======= Resulted report page: * :ref:`_Results_of_the_ETCD_health_tests` .. references: .. _Kargo: https://github.com/kubernetes-incubator/kargo.git .. _Monitoring: https://docs.openstack.org/developer/performance-docs/methodologies/monitoring/index.html .. _curl: https://curl.haxx.se/ .. _jq: https://stedolan.github.io/jq/ .. _paste: https://linux.die.net/man/1/paste .. _MMM: https://github.com/AleksandrNull/MMM .. _Hoseproxy: https://github.com/ivan4th/hoseproxy .. _CoreOS ETCD: https://coreos.com/etcd/docs/latest/metrics.html .. _Prometheus API: https://prometheus.io/docs/querying/api/ .. _Google sheets: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/ .. _Plotly: https://plot.ly/

commit_message:
Enable TripleO to Deploy Ceph via Ceph Ansible

Proposes the use of Mistral to trigger Ansible playbooks provided
by the Ceph community project ceph-ansible in order to provide an
alternative method to deploy and manage Ceph with TripleO.

Change-Id: I100ae3311540f4fb234c12f71d31aef341bbe6d9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-specs refs/changes/31/387631/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ======================================================================== Integrate TripleO with Tendrl for External Storage Deployment/Management ======================================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/tripleo/+spec/tripleo-tendrl-integration Ability to leverage Ceph management tools provided by the Ceph community. Problem Description =================== The Ceph community maintains its own tools to deploy and manage Ceph. Members of the TripleO community maintain such tools too. This is a proposal to have TripleO trigger the Ceph community's tools via an API as an alternative method to deploy and manage Ceph. Benefits of using another projects API to deploy and manage Ceph: 1. Avoid duplication of effort If there is a feature or bug fix in the Ceph community's Ceph tools not in the tools used by TripleO, then members of the TripleO community could allow deployers to use those features directly via an API instead of writing their own implementation. If this proposal is successful, then in theory it might result in not maintaining two code bases, (along with the bug fixes and testing included) in the future. However, this is not a proposal to abandon existing Ceph tools within TripleO but simply a proposal for the deployer to have the option to choose either tool. 2. Consistency between OpenStack and non-OpenStack Ceph deployments A deployer may seek assistance from the Ceph community with a Ceph deployment and this process will be simplified if both deployments were done using the same tools. 3. Enable Decoupling of Ceph management from TripleO The complexity of Ceph Management can be moved to a different tool and abstracted, where appropriate, from TripleO making the Ceph management aspect of TripleO less complex. Combining this with containerized Ceph would offer flexible deployment options. This is a deployer benefit that is difficult to deliver today. 4. Features in the Ceph community's tools not in TripleO's tools The Ceph community's tools offer benefits to OpenStack users not found in TripleO's tool chain including a business logic layer to in the code path offer additional Ceph policy based configurations as well as a graphical tool to manage and see the status of the Ceph cluster. This will allow deployers to more easily use Ceph with OpenStack. Proposed Change =============== Overview -------- Tendrl (https://github.com/Tendrl/documentation) is a framework that provides services to Storage Systems, including Ceph. This proposal assumes Tendrl will receive information via a RESTful API which it will then pass to ceph-ansible. This workflow does not suggest that TripleO directly trigger Ansible, but rather that TripleO call an API to implement a part of a deployment; similar to the way that Cinder has storage drivers. Workflow -------- TripleO's workflow to deploy a Ceph cluster would be changed so that there are two ways to deploy a Ceph cluster. If the deployer chooses this second option, then the process described below would be executed by the deployer by using TripleO, and indirectly, Tendrl. 1. Assume the following: a. The undercloud has access to the Tendrl server's API and that the Tendrl server has an IP on the TripleO's deployment network. b. The Overcloud image has the rhscon-agent package. c. The Overcloud hardware has been introspected and nodes are tagged for the ceph-storage roles and the controller roles. d. A deployer may create a custom-role which includes the ceph-mon service for a dedicated Ceph monitor. 2. Define the Overcloud on the Undercloud in Heat a. Heat parameters related to storage will later be passed to Tendrl via an API 3. Run `openstack overcloud deploy` (with standard Ceph options) 4. The undercloud assembles and uploads the deployment plan to the undercloud Swift 5. Mistral starts the workflow to deploy the Overcloud and interfaces with Heat accordingly. 6. The following point of the Deployment is reached: a. The Overcloud nodes are imaged, booted, networked, the SSH public key for heat-admin user is installed b. The Undercloud has access to the SSH private key for the heat-admin user and the provisioning or management IPs of the Overcloud nodes 7. A new Heat Resource is created which starts a Mistral workflow to Deploy Ceph. 8. A new Mistral Action Plugin makes an API call to the new Tendrl API ultimately provides: a. The SSH private key for the heat-admin user (for ceph-ansible) b. The provisioning or management IPs of the Overcloud nodes (for ceph-ansible) c. The role (mon, osd) of each Ceph machine 9. Tendrl configures ceph-ansible's host inventory with the IPs and heat-admin SSH key user. a. Alternatively, use Ansible's dynamic inventory feature that already works on OpenStack 10. Mistral asks Tendrl to confirm that ceph-ansible can `ansible mons -m ping` and `ansible osds -m ping` a. This results in ceph-ansible SSH'ing as the heat-admin user into the overcloud nodes which will host Ceph Mon or OSD services b. If this fails, the deployment fails 11. Mistral sends Tendrl the Ceph variables found in Heat 12. Tendrl updates the playbooks (or representation of) with the variables it needs from OpenStack 13. Tendrl acks to Mistral that the variables are set 14. Mistral asks Tendrl for the variables OpenStack needs from it 15. The TripleO Ceph external Heat stack is run to configure Overcloud nodes as Ceph clients 16. Mistral asks Tendrl to start the Ceph install 17. Tendrl follows its process (backed by ceph-ansible) to deploy Ceph a. Containers must be used here in order to prevent Tendrl's configurations from conflicting with TripleO's configuration. b. Today ceph-ansible supports generating a ceph.conf, and then does a "docker run"; for atomic OS it uses a systemd unit file to control the container. 18. Mistral may query Tendrl for status updates 19. Tendrl confirms the deployment is done 20. The Overcloud deployment continues as if it was using an external Ceph cluster Alternatives ------------ From a high level, this proposal _is_ an alternative to the current method of deploying Ceph with TripleO and offers the benefits listed in the problem description. From a lower level, how this proposal is implemented as described in the Workflow section should be considered. 1. Run the Tendrl server on the undercloud In step 1 of the Workflow section, it is assumed that the Tendrl server offers an API that the undercloud may access and that the Tendrl server has access to the TripleO deployment network. In the early phase of this proposal Tendrl could be a separate server in order to decouple its installation from the undercloud's installation, but in the future the Tendrl server may be able to run on the undercloud server. 2. Trigger the Tendrl Deployment before the OpenStack deployment In step 7 of the Workflow section, it is proposed that "A new Heat Resource is created which starts a Mistral workflow to Deploy Ceph". This may be difficult because, in general, composable services currently define snippets of puppet data which is then later combined to define the deployment steps, and there is not yet a way to support running an arbitrary Mistral workflow at a given step of a deployment. Thus, the Mistral workflow could be started first and then it could wait for what is described in step 6 of the overview section. 3. How will Containers will isolate configuration differences? In step 17 of the Workflow section, it is proposed that Containers be used to ensure that different configuration tools do not compete. However, how containers should be used here must still be defined and done so in a way that is compatible with how TripleO uses containers. Security Impact --------------- 1. The SSH private key for the heat-admin user is passed to the Tendrl server so that it may be used by ceph-ansible 2. An additional tool would do configuration on the Overcloud, though the impact of this should be isolated via Containers. Other End User Impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ * Mistral will need to run an additional workflow * The undercloud deployment will poll the Tendrl server for status updates * Heat's role in deploying Ceph would be lessened so the Heat stack would be smaller * If Tendrl runs on the undercloud it would consume additional resources Other Deployer Impact --------------------- * This is a change that must be explicitly enabled by the deployer. * A deployer using this option would use the same Ceph defaults as used by puppet-ceph-external.yaml but the FSID, ClientKey, and pool names would be provided by Tendrl via the API to TripleO which would then use them to configure the Ceph clients. If the same Tendrl server had stood up another Ceph cluster, then use of generated pool names, generated by Tendrl, would avoid conflicts. * The deployer does not need to set the the following values as they will have the defaults as found in Tendrl. However, the deployer may edit them in the Heat template to override those values. - ceph::profile::params::osd_journal_size - ceph::profile::params::osd_pool_default_pg_num - ceph::profile::params::osd_pool_default_pgp_num - ceph::profile::params::osd_pool_default_size - ceph::profile::params::osd_pool_default_min_size - ceph::profile::params::osd_recovery_max_active - ceph::profile::params::osd_max_backfills - ceph::profile::params::osd_recovery_op_priority * The configuration options being added are consistent with what is currently available, unless otherwise indicated, as described above. The values are ones that will work well in real deployments as determined by the Ceph community and provided in the Ceph community deployment tools that this proposal recommends making an option to TripleO deployers. * Tendrl is not specific to Ceph as it is a framework that provides services to storage systems. Thus, it is rather generic and this work could be used as an example for other integration with Tendrl. E.g. Tendrl does deploy Gluster, though that is out of scope for this specific proposal. Developer Impact ---------------- If the proposal in the Testing section were implemented then there would be an additional gate to pass. Otherwise, developers deploying Ceph could choose not to use this new alternative. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: jfulton-org Other contributors: gfidente leseb Work Items ---------- - Prototype a Heat Resource starting an independent Mistral Workflow - gfidente - Write Mistral Action Plugin to interact with Tendrl Ceph API - jfulton-org - Add option to THT for Ceph deployment to use Tendrl - Modify TripleO workflow to start Mistral Workflow for Tendrl-deployed Ceph Dependencies ============ * This requires functionality of Tendrl, another project that is not currently used by TripleO. Tendrl's API to deploy other storage, e.g. Gluster, is production-ready but it's API to deploy Ceph via ceph-ansible is being implemented at the same time as this proposed spec. * Containerization of the Ceph services provided by Tendrl is required to ensure the configuration tools aren't competing. Testing ======= A derivative work of gate-tripleo-ci-centos-7-ovb-nonha CI gate could be created which produces the same result but uses the Tendrl integration to produce the Ceph server. It would include standing up and using Tendrl server as part of it's task list. This derivative work would need extra computational resources on the existing CI hardware but could be used as an extra gate test for this feature. Documentation Impact ==================== A new TripleO Backend Configuration document "Deploying Ceph with Tendrl" would be required. References ========== * Tendrl Documentation: https://github.com/Tendrl/documentation * puppet-ceph-external.yaml: https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/stable/newton/environments/puppet-ceph-external.yaml

commit_message:
Document how to run tempest tests locally

* Add a dev document for how to run tempest tests locally.
* Pull the instruction of running unit tests out of quickstart
  guide and make it a standalone document.
* Fix the unit tests guide to make it work at Ubuntu 16.04.
* Add a sample local.conf as minimal to run devstack
* Add osprofiler guide to the index page.

Change-Id: I31794733c9225478f5df029279c8415a23b1caa0

added_lines: .. Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain a copy of the License at http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations under the License. ========================= Run tempest tests locally ========================= This is a guide for developers who want to run tempest tests in their local machine. Tempest tests are primary for testing integration between Zun and its depending software stacks (i.e. Docker, other OpenStack services, etc.). Tempest tests will be triggered on the gate for every patch submissions and it will block the merging on failure. If this happens, contributors are suggested to refer this document to re-run the tests locally and perform necessary trouble-shooting. Prerequisite ============ You need to deploy Zun in a devstack environment. Clone devstack:: # Create a root directory for devstack if needed sudo mkdir -p /opt/stack sudo chown $USER /opt/stack git clone https://git.openstack.org/openstack-dev/devstack /opt/stack/devstack We will run devstack with minimal local.conf settings required. You can use the sample local.conf as a quick-start:: git clone https://git.openstack.org/openstack/zun /opt/stack/zun cp /opt/stack/zun/devstack/local.conf.sample /opt/stack/devstack/local.conf Run devstack:: cd /opt/stack/devstack ./stack.sh **NOTE:** This will take a while to setup the dev environment. Run the test ============ Navigate to tempest directory:: cd /opt/stack/tempest Run this command:: tox -eall-plugin -- zun.tests.tempest.api --concurrency=1

commit_message:
Use SHA-256 algorithm in nova/crypto.py

Currently in nova/crypto.py, the call to 'openssl req' doesn't specify
digest option nor certificate config file sets digest, so certificates
are generated with SHA-1 digest. However, SHA-1 is not considered to
be a secure algorithm for certificates' digest.
This commit update the algorithm used in nova/crypto.py to SHA-256.

Change-Id: I222ef3580666ee229cb65fdc965142a21cdac2e7
Closes-Bug: #1516703

commit_message:
Fix ceph installation on CentOS

Tasks were copied from ceph.ceph-common/tasks/installs/redhat_ceph_repository.yml
because it's not possible to use include_role with subdirectory yet.
https://github.com/ansible/ansible/issues/20077

Change-Id: I60e769e864c26b81fd3f3fd326b414039f37080a

commit_message:
Immediately validate the state of container after checking policy

If the state of the container is not in conformity with the rules,
it will raise exception earlier and needn't handle the parameters.

Change-Id: I8251a1ef92342be8638b84b7aad1c876cacb0896

commit_message:
Add missing requirement in file definitions.yaml

The relationship outgoing from requirement “host” of the node
template “app” targets the node template “websrv”, whose type
is not compatible with those indicated in the requirement
definition corresponding to “host”.

We added in the requirement definition of the node type
"example.SomeApp" the requirement "host", so the requirement
of the node "app" is satisfied by a correct type.

Change-Id: Ibd06cabc29ddc6dc3727d4441ff3ccdda3c6aebc
Closes-bug: #1663681

commit_message:
Fix no module unit test for Python3.6

This commit fixes a unit test of 'test___init___no_module' for
Python3.6. From Python3.6, the error has been changed to
raise a ModuleNotFoundError (subclass of ImportError) when it cannot
find a module[1]. We should keep tempest working on Python3.6 although
we actually don't have py36 gate job now.

So, The testtools.ExpectedException is too strict in this situation. So
I just change it to use assertRaises. This is a bit loose to check
however, I was thinking introducing checking the semver was a bit
overkill here.

[1] https://docs.python.org/3/whatsnew/3.6.html#other-language-changes

Change-Id: I21dc50f20671780f2704d8dd18ca72e0628c8c68
Closes-Bug: #1664454

commit_message:
Close SSH connections after executing command sets

we will not rely on global requirements backport to use the context
manager newer versions of netmiko provide,
and just disconnect in 'try..finally'.

Change-Id: I8c43424f2396102ad1fc3c55a75ca3a980b70957

commit_message:
Add sem-ver flag so pbr generates correct version

tl;dr : without this Ocata and Pike have the same version causing
packaging issues.


https://docs.openstack.org/developer/pbr/#version

Because projects don't push a tag before milestone 1 (pike-1 here),
downstream packages are still building packages by using the version
from Ocata and it causes problems to distros because they can't test
the upgrades from Ocata to Pike.

Bumping the semver will allow us to test packages upgrades.
Note: When your version is X.Y.Z, api-break will bump X, and feature
will bump Y. In this patch, we bump X because this is the way you
bump tags over releases.


Change-Id: I21480e186a2aab6c54f7ea798c215660bddf9e4c
Sem-Ver: api-break

commit_message:
Make login banner customizable

This patch makes it easier for deployers to customize their login
banner and it also fixes some documentation bugs around how to
configure the graphical login banner.

subject: Short-circuit local delete path for cells v2 and InstanceNotFound
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-04-05 19:19:55.000000000', 'files': ['nova/tests/unit/compute/test_compute_api.py', 'nova/compute/api.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/5a9cc2fb7af3e3a9db44646bbd23cfcfb16891f5', 'message': "Short-circuit local delete path for cells v2 and InstanceNotFound

When we're going down the local delete path for cells v2 in the API
and instance.destroy() fails with an InstanceNotFound error, we are
racing with a concurrent delete request and know that the instance
is alread deleted, so we can just return rather than fall through to
the rest of the code in the _delete() method, like for BDMs and

Change-Id: I58690a25044d2804573451983323dde05be9e5d6

commit_message:
Short-circuit local delete path for cells v2 and InstanceNotFound

When we're going down the local delete path for cells v2 in the API
and instance.destroy() fails with an InstanceNotFound error, we are
racing with a concurrent delete request and know that the instance
is alread deleted, so we can just return rather than fall through to
the rest of the code in the _delete() method, like for BDMs and
console tokens.

Change-Id: I58690a25044d2804573451983323dde05be9e5d6
Closes-Bug: #1680211
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/40/453840/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Instance is already deleted. return

commit_message:
Added Galera SSL support

MySQL SSL connections allowed. Self-signed SSL bundle
created and placed to the deployment host, or user-provided
SSL bundle (CA, cert and the key) is used.

Change-Id: Ibac61d45cea67123fe61a6de4f906b4bd1949a34
Partial-Bug: #1667789
(cherry picked from commit eb5fc9c1e852866bc5e332a697bfeb86dfc44047)

added_lines: # Galera Server SSL functionality. galera_use_ssl: false galera_ssl_cert: /etc/mysql/ssl/galera.pem galera_ssl_key: /etc/mysql/ssl/galera.key galera_ssl_ca_cert: /etc/mysql/ssl/galera-ca.pem # These options should be specified in user_variables if necessary, otherwise self-signed certs are used. galera_user_ssl_cert: /etc/openstack_deploy/self_signed_certs/galera.pem galera_user_ssl_key: /etc/openstack_deploy/self_signed_certs/galera.key galera_user_ssl_ca_cert: /etc/openstack_deploy/self_signed_certs/galera-ca.pem # Set galera_ssl_self_signed_regen to true if you want to generate a new # SSL certificate for Galera when this playbook runs. You can also change # the subject of the self-signed certificate here if you prefer. galera_ssl_self_signed_regen: false galera_ssl_self_signed_subject: "/C=US/ST=Texas/L=San Antonio/O=IT/CN={{ galera_ssl_address }}" galera_ssl_ca_self_signed_subject: "/C=US/ST=Texas/L=San Antonio/O=IT" # This option is used for creating the CA and overriding the Galera address on the clients side. # Should be set to either public VIP of VIP FQDN, depending on what is currently used in the env. galera_ssl_address: "{{ ansible_host }}"

commit_message:
Use cinder timeout variables for upstart

Change Ib4381e092e15834c692b2fd76a2f41bf6fed28dd introduced the
cinder_sigkill_timeout and cinder_restart_wait variables, but the
backports did not introduce these for the upstart scripts.

This patch adds them so that upstart and systemd configurations on
Newton are the same.

Change-Id: If70cfeae64a78fb1a9d126e2677ae4b5c45e08b5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_cinder refs/changes/67/453267/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Change intermediary vm state handling
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-04-05 15:14:59.000000000', 'files': ['os_win/utils/compute/vmutils.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/os-win/commit/7e8aca1642a1476b4f19f90b7732ffe912be82b0', 'message': "Change intermediary vm state handling

os-win reports vms in intermediary power states as being running
(we're actualy stating this in an inline comment).

For some reason, one exception to this rule is the 'shutting down'
power state, for which we define a separate vm state.

The Nova Hyper-V driver then treats this speific state as a shutoff
state. This confuses the Nova manager in case of rebooting instances,
treating this as an unexpected instance shutdown, forcing a shutdown

Closes-Bug: #1660978

(cherry picked from commit 86c619211c38fd59253b287a3f67b4f5b827c93a)

commit_message:
Change intermediary vm state handling

os-win reports vms in intermediary power states as being running
(we're actualy stating this in an inline comment).

For some reason, one exception to this rule is the 'shutting down'
power state, for which we define a separate vm state.

The Nova Hyper-V driver then treats this speific state as a shutoff
state. This confuses the Nova manager in case of rebooting instances,
treating this as an unexpected instance shutdown, forcing a shutdown
afterwards.

While this should be fixed in the Nova driver as well, simply remaining
consistent with the above mentioned rule and reporting all intermediary
states as 'active' at the os-win level will mitigate the issue.

Closes-Bug: #1660978

Change-Id: I82bc176e17606684d4a88adaa99a171360e13e04
(cherry picked from commit 86c619211c38fd59253b287a3f67b4f5b827c93a)

commit_message:
Fix share local address check

We're resolving share addresses to determine if those point to a
local address. The issue is that we fetch the local ips resolving
the local hostname, which won't include '127.0.0.1' or '::1'.

For this reason, a share such as '\\localhost\share' won't be
reported as being local.

This change handles this case.

Closes-Bug: #1680029

Change-Id: I36df4aa79bb7af548b6e39f9f9e7c4f979ae0a77
(cherry picked from commit 54d97f24773d74eb1a158c9b4ac8f9360dd56665)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/os-win refs/changes/04/453704/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: local_ips += _utils.get_ips('localhost')

commit_message:
Enable idempotence test

Tasks involved in the online install of pip have been made idempotent
and the idempotence test has been enabled.

The selfcheck.json file will only be written if it does not already
exist. Blocks have been added to tasks that have a fallback if they
fail. Tasks that run commands to install or download pip packages now
check stdout for success messages to determine if they should be marked
changed.

Change-Id: I0d440efd4d95420f6f43316f5e0242b8884293c8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-pip_install refs/changes/36/453836/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: TEST_IDEMPOTENCE=true

commit_message:
Add suse family package map

This patch adds SUSE package names to the infra-package-needs nodepool
element so that openSUSE images can be built.

Change-Id: Icca774ddad92d8d5c96f73627f07b57bd0e96e77

subject: Add regression test for quota decrement bug 1678326
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-03-31 23:59:26.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/dcb4b342efd6fb4d6ffd226dbbcd0064e82743c5', 'message': 'Add regression test for quota decrement bug 1678326

This was spotted from someone validating the fix for
bug 1670627. They reported that even though they failed
to delete an instance in ERROR state that was in cell0,
the quota usage was decremented.

This is because we are committed the quota reservation
to decrement the usage before actually attempting to destroy
the instance, rather than upon successful deletion.

The rollback after InstanceNotFound is a noop because of
how the Quotas.rollback method noops if the reservations
were already committed. That is in itself arguably a bug,
but not fixed here, especially since the counting quotas
work in Pike will remove all of the reservations commit and
rollback code.

This also fixes another bug where we would not short-circuit
and return from _delete if we hit InstanceNotFound.

Change-Id: I12d1fa1a10f9014863123ac9cc3c63ddfb48378e
Partial-Bug: #1678326

commit_message:
Add regression test for quota decrement bug 1678326

This was spotted from someone validating the fix for
bug 1670627. They reported that even though they failed
to delete an instance in ERROR state that was in cell0,
the quota usage was decremented.

This is because we committed the quota reservation
to decrement the usage before actually attempting to destroy
the instance, rather than upon successful deletion.

The rollback after InstanceNotFound is a noop because of
how the Quotas.rollback method noops if the reservations
were already committed. That is in itself arguably a bug,
but not fixed here, especially since the counting quotas
work in Pike will remove all of the reservations commit and
rollback code.

Change-Id: I12d1fa1a10f9014863123ac9cc3c63ddfb48378e
Partial-Bug: #1678326

commit_message:
Use Sphinx 1.5 warning-is-error

With pbr 2.0 and Sphinx 1.5, the setting for treat sphinx warnings as
errors is setting warning-is-error in build_sphinx section. Migrate
the setting from the old warnerrors one.

The history document is removed because some of the commit messages used
in ChangeLog were being identified as invalid markup and there doesn't
appear to be anyway to edit there retroactively nor disable warnings on
a specific file.

Change-Id: I79e7ac56d5af1151865686761f3d40a11efbf472
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging refs/changes/96/446596/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: warning-is-error = 1 all-files = 1

commit_message:
tox: Build docs with Python 2.7

The 'list-modules' directive used in some docs does not appear to be
Python 3 compatible, yielding the following error:

  TypeError: unorderable types: NoneType() < str()

Simply use Python 2.7 until such a time as someone wants to investigate
why this happens.

Change-Id: I0be19b056e1c2272df3666626fbd17ec78017bce
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging refs/changes/95/446595/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Commit usage decrement after destroying instance

This fixes a regression in Ocata where we were always
decrementing quota usage during instance delete even
if we failed to delete the instance. Now the reservation
is properly committed after the instance is destroyed.

The related functional test is updated to show this working
correctly now.

Change-Id: I5200e72c195e12b5a069cbae3f209492ed569fb4
Closes-Bug: #1678326

deleted_lines: quotas.commit() quotas.commit() return # Instance is already deleted. return

commit_message:
Fix protocol value to icmpv6 in IPv6 scenario tests

Currently tempest is creating a Security Group rule with ethertype=IPv6
and protocol=icmp before validating ping6 use-cases. Ideally, tempest
should configure SG rule with protocol=icmpv6 instead of icmp. This patch
fixes this issue.

Closes-Bug: #1671366
Change-Id: I87063d20becec12c1b52402abe4d3bd9888ebc57
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/44/443444/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: [Urgent] Add __contains__ method to FakeSession
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-04-06 11:07:14.000000000', 'files': ['tricircle/tests/unit/network/test_central_plugin.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tricircle/commit/ab046fba3a108f90cefbe1e9adb48744af21297d', 'message': '[Urgent] Add __contains__ method to FakeSession

1. What is the problem?
After a recent update, Neutron will use "subnet in context.session"
to check if the session contatins subnet object. However, our
simulated class for Session in the unit tests, FakeSession, is not
iterable. Thus unit tests fail.

2. What is the solution to the problem?
Add __contains__ method to FakeSession class to make it support
"in" operation.

3. What the features need to be implemented to the Tricircle
to realize the solution?
No new features. Changes to pass unit tests.

Change-Id: I26689fdd86e1cce04b9178576646b481762fb0d6
'}]
commit_message:
[Urgent] Add __contains__ method to FakeSession

1. What is the problem?
After a recent update, Neutron will use "subnet in context.session"
to check if the session contatins subnet object. However, our
simulated class for Session in the unit tests, FakeSession, is not
iterable. Thus unit tests fail.

2. What is the solution to the problem?
Add __contains__ method to FakeSession class to make it support
"in" operation.

3. What the features need to be implemented to the Tricircle
to realize the solution?
No new features. Changes to pass unit tests.

Change-Id: I26689fdd86e1cce04b9178576646b481762fb0d6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tricircle refs/changes/03/454103/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def __contains__(self, item): return False

commit_message:
Install more packages with DIB

Eventually we don't want to be running puppet to create nodepool images.
This patch adds all the packages that were declared as puppet package
resources in openstack_project::template[1] to the infra-package-needs
element so that they will exist on the image with our without puppet
managing them.

[1] http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack-infra/system-config/tree/modules/openstack_project/manifests/template.pp#n167

Change-Id: Ie1a0aba57390c9c0b269b4cbb076090ae1de73a9

(cherry picked from commit c093c13e01826da545bf9a0259e0be441bc1b5e1)

commit_message:
Remove os-cloud-config from Infra

Step 3 of https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/drivers.html#retiring-a-project

Removing os-cloud-config from Zuul, and set the project as read only in
Gerrit.

Good bye os-cloud-config :-)

Change-Id: I8713db283ddd9dc4f0dd885476694dd8e5ed1bf3

commit_message:
Remove British English translations

British English translations were useful for testing the translation
jobs but I don't think anyone is actually interested (I'm the only one
who worked on it).

If someone wants it back, the automated job will automatically propose
the language again when the translations ratio gets over 75% on Zanata.

Change-Id: I6b2d6207af805351e84040c39b79c3098d0f680a
Closes-Bug: #1680397

Disable Ceilometer API by default on undercloud

Ceilometer API has already been deprecated in Ocata. Lets stop
deploying it by default on undercloud.

Closes-bug: #1676968

commit_message:
Add a new command to get the overcloudrc files

If a user deploys via the GUI, then this file wont automatically be
created. We can now create it via a Mistral action - this command
provides CLI users a way to call that action and save the file.

While adding tests a typo was spotted in utils.py, this is also resolved
by this patch and covered by the tests.

Change-Id: I7808cd2c43a95bbb154ec6c6f77896b97551e354
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-tripleoclient refs/changes/54/404354/16 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: overcloud_credentials = tripleoclient.v1.overcloud_credentials:OvercloudCredentials

commit_message:
Don't use cache directory in home user dir with sudo

When running instack with sudo there are created directories owned
by root in users ~/.cache folder with is default for
DIB_IMAGE_CACHE. Then it's impossible to run DIB as user using
the same cache dir.

Change-Id: I42f5e6db85b3571ed2f393160214928f18c0b145
Closes-Bug: #1668939
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/instack refs/changes/06/441706/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: os.environ['DIB_IMAGE_CACHE'] = '/tmp/.cache/image-create'

commit_message:
pike: release python-novaclient 8.0.0

This is a major version bump because we're dropping several
deprecated CLIs and APIs.

Change-Id: I34b7084c4d70cb61a61355b53ecb634932025bb2
Depends-On: Ib3468b93e2b396fa1372d3df4be4454f8bc64314
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/releases refs/changes/19/453819/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: release-notes: https://docs.openstack.org/releasenotes/python-novaclient/unreleased.html releases: - version: 7.0.0 projects: - repo: openstack/python-novaclient hash: e1b9e76abe6731d7d3192566db2f9068a71eaad9 highlights: > - Deprecated proxy APIs and CLIs to other services such as the image, volume, baremetal and networking service, have been deleted. - Log translations have been removed. - Updated dependencies.

commit_message:
Add 'cliff-commands' Sphinx directive

This is a variant of the 'cliff-command' directive that supports
wildcarding of commands names.

Change-Id: I3528096a1a53a51b5b45cf2ba7177041718a70a7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cliff refs/changes/83/453383/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: cliff supports integration with Sphinx by way of two `Sphinx directives`__... rst:directive:: cliff-commands The same as :rst:dir:`cliff-command`, only with support for multiple commands. `:prog:` is optional and, if defined, is an `fnmatch-style`__ wildcard. :: .. cliff-commands:: :namespace: openstack.compute.v2 :prog: server * You could also register all of these at once like so:: .. cliff-commands:: :namespace: openstack.compute.v2 :prog: host * In any case, you should add the following to your `conf.py` to ensure all usage__ https://docs.python.org/3/library/fnmatch.html
deleted_lines: cliff supports integration with Sphinx by way of a `Sphinx directive`__.In addition, you should add the following to your `conf.py` to ensure all usage

commit_message:
Fix flavor info in server response schema

Nova show flavor info(id and link) in the server representation
but those are not always going to be present.

If flavor data is being deleted from DB after server creation then,
it will return empty dict. But Tempest schema expect a non-empty dict
always.

Fixing doc for that on nova side- I350dc33df0cb03eb86df1f142e58ae34b02a1334

Also we are not loosing any coverage due to relaxing this in schema as tests
does checks the flavor object presence for normal case where flavor should
be present in server representation.
- test_resize_server_confirm
- test_rebuild_server

Change-Id: I274a86112d78c469970b62334a4301b107a75c5a
Closes-Bug: #1677953

commit_message:
Add apache related macros

SUSE and Fedora have some differences in the apache setup. Add some
macros starting with "apache_" to handle the differences in the spec
files.

(cherry picked from commit 4e5e178a559832d47c96a26dc37f14d2ae440004)

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-04-06 06:48:15.000000000', 'files': ['jenkins/scripts/common_translation_update.sh'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/0aff53764b2267567c0b799ef48b7b0661d4e65a', 'message': 'Babel 2.4 workaround with Locales using '-'

Currently building of locales fails like
http://logs.openstack.org/8d/8d993d3bbd17ce22288b9ea9caa6d93618522f46/post/openstack-manuals-tox-doc-publishlang/53125a3/console.html#_2017-04-05_07_35_50_515860

'}]
commit_message:
Babel 2.4 workaround with Locales using '-'

Currently building of locales fails like
http://logs.openstack.org/8d/8d993d3bbd17ce22288b9ea9caa6d93618522f46/post/openstack-manuals-tox-doc-publishlang/53125a3/console.html#_2017-04-05_07_35_50_515860

with:
"ValueError: expected only letters, got u'ko-kr'"

Reported as bug at:
https://github.com/python-babel/babel/issues/489

Convert language codes with '-' to use '_' to conform with Babel
expectations.

Change-Id: I41c4e29cdaeaf9e1030319408e2914e945a7bb92
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/97/453997/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Zanata uses '-' in language codes but Babel expects '_'. # Convert 'ko-KR' and similar to 'ko_KR': sed -e 's/^"Language: \(.*\)-\(.*\)"/"Language: \1_\2"/' -i $i

commit_message:
Role based resource access control - delete executions

We already supported role based api access control, this series patches
will implement resource access control for mistral, so that
administrator could define the rules of resource accessibility, e.g.
admin user could get/delete/update the workflows of other tenants
according to the policy.

Delete executions by admin already supported after following patch
merged: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/451160/

This patch adds some tests.

Partially implements: blueprint mistral-rbac

Change-Id: I918708d5bf76abdf2c2c08bb147fa50bd715f526
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/mistral refs/changes/55/451255/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_delete_workflow_execution_by_admin(self): with db_api.transaction(): created = db_api.create_workflow_execution(WF_EXECS[0]) fetched = db_api.get_workflow_execution(created.id) self.assertEqual(created, fetched) auth_context.set_ctx(ADM_CTX) db_api.delete_workflow_execution(created.id) auth_context.set_ctx(DEFAULT_CTX) self.assertRaises( exc.DBEntityNotFoundError, db_api.get_workflow_execution, created.id ) def test_delete_workflow_execution_by_other_fail(self): created = db_api.create_workflow_execution(WF_EXECS[0]) auth_context.set_ctx(USER_CTX) self.assertRaises( exc.DBEntityNotFoundError, db_api.delete_workflow_execution, created.id )

commit_message:
Requirements file missing python-virtualenv

On systems where python-virtualenv is not installed, rally fails
to run. As such adding the package to requirements required for
running rally.

Change-Id: Ib95331bab90d0926750548704ac4ba7e997d72f1
Closes-Bug: #1678047
(cherry picked from commit 93ee5102e839564807dda71d072d07ca820a62e4)

commit_message:
Create domains in keystone after LDAP domain configurations

Since we're using the file-based approach for LDAP backends. We need to
issue a "domain create" via the keystone API before keystone can read
the desired configurations. After doing this we then need to restart the
keystone server, so it takes the new configurations into account, given
the created domains. This is unpractical for operators.

This attempts to automate that by creating the desired domains
via puppet, however a restart of httpd is still needed.

Change-Id: I84a001ef9894542caa72f0a831460832b9fd93e2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-tripleo refs/changes/32/454032/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Use web repo with installed packages for image build

When building images we need to supply repo with built packages
to DIB so it will use when installing packages on the image.
Because DIB is in a chrooted environment we have to use repo in
network. This patch runs a webserver on the directory of the
repository to make it accessible over HTTP on port 8766.

Change-Id: I7b21d3ff1ec7cecab322e599cb929259f5a7256e

commit_message:
Add reno for cluster_user_trust option

Add release notes for the new configuration parameter
cluster_user_trust which was introduced in the fix
for CVE-2016-7404.

(cherry picked from 4d4e98157ecf9b880ef409f2256eca2d0466f40b)

Change-Id: I0d7acfeb7ba906f10fedfe2c13f213dadf96c37f
Related-Bug: #1620536
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/magnum refs/changes/98/450698/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- upgrade: - | To let clusters communicate directly with OpenStack service other than Magnum, in the `trust` section of magnum.conf, set `cluster_user_trust` to True. The default value is False. security: - | Every magnum cluster has assigned to a trustee user and a trustID. This user is used to allow clusters communicate with the key-manager service (Barbican) and get the certificate authority of the cluster. This trust user can be used by other services too. It can be used, to let the cluster authenticate with other OpenStack services like the Block Storage service, Object Storage service, Load Balancing etc. The cluster with this user and the trustID has full access to the trustor's OpenStack project. A new configuration parameter has been added to restict the access to other services than Magnum. fixes: - | Fixes CVE-2016-7404 for newly created clusters. Existing clusters will have to be recreated to benefit from this fix. Part of this fix is the newly introduced setting `cluster_user_trust` in the `trust` section of magnum.conf. This setting defaults to False. `cluster_user_trust` dictates whether to allow passing a trust ID into a cluster's instances. For most clusters this is capability is not needed. Clusters with `registry_enabled=True` or `volume_driver=rexray` will need this capability. Other features that require this capability may be introduced in the future. To be able to create such clusters you will need to set `cluster_user_trust` to True.

commit_message:
Surpress log with context data and db data

When debugging mistral workflow with openstack actions in multi-region
environment, there are a lot of huge blocks containing openstack
service catalog in the log file. It's not necessary to print the whole
context data sometimes.

What's more, we should avoid logging whole database instance
information. Let's keep the log useful and simple.

Change-Id: I415ea40517fb00936cfcdaab8fac1243689b0187

commit_message:
Add extra_info field to the resource database table of plan API

Add the extra_info field to the resource database table of
plan API datamodule. User can save the extra_info of resourece
instances to this table.

Co-authored-by: xiangxinyong <xiangxinyong@huawei.com>

blueprint instances-extra-info
Change-Id: I2efa0df5489ce7dc7ef9dff1c187536d8fe27af5

commit_message:
Set a dependency on collector

Its better to restart collector after the ceilo-upgrade is done
so that the dispatchers are loaded and communicate with other
services like gnocchi and panko and dispatch data. Otherwise
user has to retsrat collector sometimes.

Closes-bug: #1680126

Change-Id: Ib23913d698199ca87658e28e99acb5d56cebd858
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/instack-undercloud refs/changes/96/453696/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: docker-puppet.py fail if any worker fails
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-03-09 02:22:11.000000000', 'files': ['docker/docker-puppet.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/af03e4d34bffcabd26e72eb85137b91f348ee2cb', 'message': 'docker-puppet.py fail if any worker fails

Currently returncodes are ignored from docker puppet workers, so a
failed puppet apply may not manifest until later in the stack
deployment due to some other failure.

This change logs any failures at the end of the run and returns a
failure code if any worker returns a failure code.

Change-Id: I6a504dbeb4c0ac465ce10e7647830524fe0a1160
'}]
commit_message:
docker-puppet.py fail if any worker fails

Currently returncodes are ignored from docker puppet workers, so a
failed puppet apply may not manifest until later in the stack
deployment due to some other failure.

This change logs any failures at the end of the run and returns a
failure code if any worker returns a failure code.

Change-Id: I6a504dbeb4c0ac465ce10e7647830524fe0a1160

commit_message:
Don't treat redundant nodes as warning

If there are nodes that are not going to be deployed now, it's
normal situation, don't treat it as warning and fail deploy.
It could be used to later scaling for example.

Change-Id: I8d79d6b4a0dcabb08e474e99be185950c8e79a18
